definition: to come to accept an unpleasant fact/to get over sth/to cheer up
to see/to look at/to read/to watch/to visit/to call on/to consider/to regard as/to look after/to treat (an illness)/to depend on/to feel (that)/(after verb) to give it a try/Watch out! (for a danger)
to look after/to take care of/to watch/to guard

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: I hope you see open a point.
Take it easy, there are as many morons in China as in the US of A.
sentences.chinese: 看开点儿，中国跟美国情况一样，也有很多傻瓜。

sentences.english: This is a non-event and China will get over it.
sentences.chinese: 在这个不算事件的问题上，中国将会看开的。

definition: to regard as unimportant/to be indifferent to (fame, wealth etc)/(of an economy or a market) to slacken
to not take to heart/to be free of worried thoughts/to adopt a lighthearted perspective/lighthearted
to release (tension)/relief (from suspense)/to dispel (usu. with negative, unable to forget)
relieved/at ease/feel relieved
lit. can pick it up or put it down (idiom)/fig. to take what comes/to meet gains or losses with equanimity
pinyin: na2 de5 qi3 fang4 de5 xia4

definition: to achieve supreme enlightenment or nirvana (Buddhism)
lit. silly people get their panties in a bunch (idiom)/fig. to get upset over nothing/to make problems for oneself
to let nature take its course (idiom)
to bring trouble on oneself (idiom)
at home wherever one is (idiom); ready to adapt/flexible/to accept circumstances with good will
to figure out/to realize/to become convinced/to come round (to an idea)/to get over it
to see through the world of mortals (idiom, of Buddhist monk)/disillusioned with human society/to reject the world for a monastic life
to understand thoroughly/to see beyond the facade/to see through (sb)
lit. to penetrate into a bull's horn (idiom); fig. to waste time on an insoluble or insignificant problem/to bash one's head against a brick wall/a wild goose chase/a blind alley/to split hairs
levelheadedness/calmness/equanimity

nothing sadder than a withered heart (idiom attributed to Confucius by Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子[Zhuang1 zi3])/no greater sorrow than a heart that never rejoices/the worst sorrow is not as bad as an uncaring heart/nothing is more wretched than apathy
pinyin: ai1 mo4 da4 yu2 xin1 si3
